messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:30): Shelley's mention of RSS 1.0 is interesting, because after flirting with RDF, the feed community knowingly moved away from RDF
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:31): also, Mozilla implemented RDF when it was a new and unproven thing and has since moved away from using RDF internally
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:50): per definition all the xmlns="" and xmlns:<foo>="" attributes are different in HTML and XML
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:50): apart from that, everything is equal I think
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:50): as far as RDFa goes
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (20:52): "SVG and MathML had valid use cases. Therefore RDFa must be added for no real reason."

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:01): And I still have no votes.

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:02): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Going back to your link
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:02): "(...) any realization of a Semantic Web will depend on structured data."
0c25ae3066f1b9f7890ceff405fdcab1 (21:03): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I see four votes for you under "all of the above"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:03): 0c25ae3066f1b9f7890ceff405fdcab1: Smartass.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:03): So not only is RDF axiomatically going to happen, the semantic web is too
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:03): Hmmm‚Ä¶
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:03): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, great, guess we don't have to do anything then :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:03): $x = \frac{16}{b-1}$
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:04): $x$ and $b$ are natural numbers.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:04): no math post-5PM
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:04): There is a sequence, x, x + 8, bx.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Fix the mathml bug
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:04): What possible values of x and b are there?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:04): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I have a maths exam on Monday, thus maths will appear after 17:00
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:04): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, what MathML bug?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:05): The one where we only render the first part in a mfenced
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:05): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, they can appear after 17:00, but only if it's also after 5:00
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:05): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: It is currently after 5:00.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:05): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, if by we you mean Opera, yeah, we should just do MathML natively
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:05): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, true, I meant the 5:00 that comes after 17:00 though
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:05): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Multiply by b-1 and factorize?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:05): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, i.e. tomorrow
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:06): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Oh, I didn't realize.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:06): :P
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:06): chuckles at time format humour, sadly.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:07): x(b-1) = 16‚Ä¶
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:07): wonders how to factorize that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:08): blatently sucks at maths
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:10): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I suggest finding the factors of 16
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:10): Try x = any divisor of 16 (including negative) and see if it works
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:11): Oh, that's only prime factors, which isn't so useful
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:11): It's not that hard to work them out :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:12): and it should work for all.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:12): according to the answers.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:12): Since b-1 divides 16, b-1 must be 1 or 2 or 8 or 16 and it's trivial to find x
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:15): did Opera include some RDF APIs at some point? I can't find documentation.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I don't think so
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:16): oh. interesting
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:17): all we support is the RDF meaning RSS 1.0 ...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:19): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: do you parse it into a graph?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (21:22): no
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:33): Hmm, for all those (i.e., (x,b) = (1.17)‚Ä¶(16,2)) "calculate the sum of the first 10 terms". So, using $0.5*10(x+(10-1)8)$ I get the wrong answers
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:33): But s/x/2x/ gives the right answers.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:33): (Assuming the given answsers are correct)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:33): *answers
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:34): Why would it be 2x?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:35): First ten in what order?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:35): First ten of what?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:36): The arithmetic sequence x, x + 8, bx
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:36): That's not a sequence, it's just three numbers
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:36): (for which we found possible values of x and b)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:36): Sorry, that's the first three terms of the sequence
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:36): So the sequence should be, I think, x + (n-1)8
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:37): I don't think this qualifies as well-defined
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:37): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: That's normal in this textbook.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:37): :(
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:37): You're holding out on us
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): Yet the only way this works for the final part of the question is 2x + (n-1)8
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): Which inevitably breaks what I asked above
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:38): Why don't you tell us the whole question :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Because Im lazy? :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:38): x + (n-1)8 doesn't look like it involves b at all
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (21:39): arithmetic sequences you can solve given only two terms
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (21:40): well, two terms and you know what number those are
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:41): That's true but, I think, irrelevant :-p
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:42): Oh, maybe not
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:42): "The arithmetic sequence x, x + 8, bx" is only an arithmetic sequence if bx = x+16
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:42): and the earlier condition on b and x means that's true
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:42): http://pastebin.ca/1311084
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:42): There's the full question.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:43): ... that's a very different question!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:43): The bx part is completely irrelevant in the final part.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:43): And ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c answered it
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:43): Where?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:43): is blind
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:44): Guess you're out of luck then :(
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:44): :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:44): The final part it gives answers 370‚Äì520.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:44): I got 365‚Äì440.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:46): The first term in the sequence is x, the tenth term is x+8*9, so the mean is (x+x+8*9)/2 and the sum is 10*(x+x+8*9)/2
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:46): which is 5x+36
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:46): If the sequence were $2x + (n - 1)8$ for the $n$th term, and not $x + (n-1)8$, I would get those answers
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:47): Wait, I can't do arithmetic
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That disagrees with both me and the textbook
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:47): so the answers are 370, 520, etc
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:48): It should be $0.5n(x+(n-1)8)$
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:48): Oh wait.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:48): I think you're missing a +x in the middle
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:48): I can't read.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:48): It should be 2x
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:49): can't read the textbook
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:50): Scary problem: I'm meant to know a large number of equations on Monday
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:50): You shouldn't know the equations, you should just know how to derive them :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: deriving everything from axioms in a test takes time
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (21:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that's how I survived AP Physics

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Yeah, I do that with the computing things (mainly we are meant to remember algorithms). But in maths, as b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, it takes precious time.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:51): (e.g. I don't know the equation for summing arithmetic sequences, but I know it's the average of the first and last terms multiplied by the number of terms)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:52): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: You don't need to start from the axioms and produce a formal proof, so it's not quite that bad :-)
